questions.text: What is the mode of inheritance in a patient suffering from colour blindness?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) XLR

Explanation:

  • The mode of inheritance in a patient suffering from colour blindness is X-linked recessive (XLR).

X-Linked Recessive:

  • The gene for Color blindness is located on the X chromosome.
  • Males (XY) express the disorder if they inherit the affected X chromosome since they lack a second X for compensation.
  • Females (XX) can be carriers if they inherit one affected X chromosome, often showing no symptoms due to the normal allele on the other X.
  • Affected males cannot pass the disorder to sons but can pass the affected X to daughters, making them carriers.

X-linked Recessive

(WISE ABCDEFGH)

Wise-Wiskott Aldrich Syndrome

AB- Hemophilia A, B

B- Bruton's Hypogammaglobulinemia.

C- Chronic Granulomatous Disease, Red Green Color Blindness

D- DMD, BMD

E- Lesch Nyhan Syndrome

F- Fabry Disease, Fragile X Syndrome

G- G6PD Deficiency

H- Hunter Disease

 

Incorrect Options:

Autosomal Dominant (AD) (Option A) disorders affect both sexes equally, and only one mutated allele is required for the disease to manifest.

  • Examples: Marfan syndrome, Achondroplasia, Familial hypercholesterolemia.

Autosomal Recessive (AR) (Option B) disorders require both alleles to be mutated for disease manifestation.

  • Examples: Cystic fibrosis, Sickle cell disease, Phenylketonuria (PKU). Colour blindness is inherited in an X-linked pattern, not AR.

X-linked Dominant (XLD) (Option D) affects both males and females, but females more commonly due to having two X chromosomes.

  • Examples: Rett syndrome, Fragile X syndrome, and Hypophosphatemic rickets. Colour blindness is X-linked recessive, not dominant.

questions.text: Which of the following correctly represents the effect of the mutation causing sickle cell anaemia?

choices.text: Glutamate by valine at the 6th position
Valine by glutamate at the 6th position
Glutamate by valine at the 5th position
Valine by glutamate at the 5th position

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Glutamate by valine at the 6th position

Explanation:

  • Sickle cell anaemia is caused by a point mutation that involves substituting adenine for thymine at the sixth codon of the β-globin gene (GAG to GTG), replacing glutamic acid (glutamate) with valine in the β-globin chain of haemoglobin.
  • This single nucleotide change results in the formation of abnormal haemoglobin molecules (HbS).
  • After deoxygenation, HbS molecules polymerize to form bundles.
  • These polymer bundles cause erythrocytes to adopt a sickle shape and also promote hemolysis of erythrocytes, releasing cell-free Hb into circulation.

questions.text: B cells express IgM and IgD antibodies at the same time. Which phenomenon is it due to?
questions.solution:
B cells express IgM and IgD antibodies simultaneously due to alternative RNA splicing. This process allows the same gene for the heavy chain to be spliced in different ways to produce both IgM and IgD isotypes.

 

  • The IgM and IgD are both produced from the same heavy chain gene but are differentiated through this splicing mechanism.
  • During this process, the RNA transcript for the heavy chain is spliced in two different ways, one to produce IgM and the other to produce IgD.
  • Both these antibodies have the same antigen-binding specificity but differ in their constant regions, which define their isotypes.

 

Somatic hypermutation (Option A) occurs after antigen exposure and increases antibody affinity, but it does not affect the simultaneous expression of IgM and IgD.

 

Affinity maturation (Option C) is a process that occurs during the immune response to improve the affinity of antibodies, not to generate multiple antibody classes at the same time.

 

Allelic exclusion (Option D) ensures that only one allele of the immunoglobulin gene is expressed in a B cell at any given time, which helps in maintaining clonal specificity, but it does not explain the co-expression of IgM and IgD.

questions.text: Differential expression of a gene depending upon the parent of origin is a feature of:
questions.solution:
Genomic imprinting refers to the phenomenon where the expression of a gene depends on which parent the gene was inherited from. In imprinted genes, one allele is silenced depending on the parent of origin, leading to differential expression.

 

Genomic imprinting:

  • Inheritance: We inherit two copies of each autosomal gene, one from each parent, but functional differences can exist between the maternal and paternal alleles.
  • Mechanism: Imprinting is an epigenetic process that selectively inactivates either the maternal or paternal allele. Maternal imprinting silences the maternal allele, while paternal imprinting silences the paternal allele.
  • Imprinting occurs in the ovum or sperm before fertilization.
  • The imprinting pattern is stably transmitted to somatic cells through mitosis.
  • Imprinting is linked to disorders like Prader-Willi syndrome and Angelman syndrome.


 

Prader-Willi syndrome

Chromosome 15q

SNORP gene
  • Paternal deletion
  • Maternal imprinting

Angelman syndrome

Chromosome 15q

UBE3A gene
  • Maternal deletion
  • Paternal imprinting

 

Gonadal mosaicism (Option A) refers to a condition where some of an individual's gametes (eggs or sperm) carry a mutation that is not present in the somatic cells. It does not involve differential expression based on the parent of origin, which is specific to genomic imprinting.

 

Anticipation (Option C) refers to the phenomenon where a genetic disorder becomes more severe or appears at an earlier age with each successive generation. It is seen in trinucleotide repeat disorders.

 

Incomplete penetrance (Option D) refers to situations where an individual with a disease-causing genotype does not show the expected phenotype.

Example: BRCA1 gene mutations, which increase the risk of breast and ovarian cancer. Some individuals with the mutation never develop cancer despite carrying the gene.

questions.text: In cystic fibrosis, which of the following structures is affected in the pancreas?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) B

 

Explanation:

"B" represents the acini, the functional units of the exocrine pancreas that produce and secrete digestive enzymes into the pancreatic ducts, and these are affected in Cystic Fibrosis, an autosomal recessive genetic disorder.

 

Pathogenesis:

  • It is caused by mutations in the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) gene, resulting in a defect in the production or function of the CFTR protein.
  • This leads to thick, sticky mucus forming in various organs, including the pancreas.
  • In the pancreas, the defective CFTR protein affects the secretion of chloride ions and water, dehydrating pancreatic secretions.
  • This thickened mucus obstructs the pancreatic ducts, preventing the proper flow of digestive enzymes from the acini into the duodenum. (Option B)
  • Consequently, there is a reduction in the production and release of pancreatic enzymes, leading to impaired digestion and malabsorption of nutrients.

 

Clinical features:

 

Respiratory system

Gastrointestinal and hepatic

Others
  • Progressive airway obstruction
  • Infective exacerbations of bronchiectasis
  • Respiratory failure
  • Spontaneous pneumothorax
  • Haemoptysis
  • Lobar collapse due to secretions
  • Pulmonary hypertension
  • Nasal polyps
  • Malabsorption and steatorrhoea
  • Distal intestinal obstruction syndrome
  • Biliary cirrhosis
  • Portal hypertension, varices, and splenomegaly
  • Gallstones
  • Diabetes
  • Delayed puberty,
  • Male infertility
  • Stress incontinence due to repeated forced cough
  • Psychosocial problems
  • Osteoporosis
  • Arthropathy
  • Cutaneous vasculitis

 

A (Option A) is the islets of Langerhans, responsible for the production and secretion of hormones such as insulin and glucagon. It is not the target of cystic fibrosis.

 

C (Option C) is the intralobular duct, which is part of the pancreatic duct system and plays a role in transporting pancreatic enzymes. It is not the target of cystic fibrosis.

 

D (Option D) is the interlobular duct that transports pancreatic secretions and is not the target of cystic fibrosis.

questions.text: A karyotyping image is given below. What are the clinical features most likely to be expected in such patients?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Gynecomastia and long limbs

Explanation:

The karyotype image reveals an additional X chromosome, confirming the presence of Klinefelter Syndrome (47, XXY), a condition often associated with features like gynecomastia and longer limbs.

  • It is male hypogonadism resulting from two or more X chromosomes and one or more Y chromosomes.
  • It is an important genetic cause of reduced spermatogenesis and male infertility.
  • Karyotype: The most common is 47, XXY, from meiotic nondisjunction; some have mosaic patterns (e.g., 46, XY/47, XXY).
  • X chromosome genes: Some genes escape inactivation, leading to uneven dosage compensation and overexpression.
  • Clinical features of Klinefelter syndrome:
    • Gynecomastia (breast development)
    • Long limbs
    • Infertility (most common cause of male hypogonadism and infertility).

 

Flat occiput (Option B) is a feature of Down syndrome (Trisomy 21), a genetic condition caused by an extra chromosome 21, leading to intellectual disability, developmental delays, and physical traits like a flat face and almond-shaped eyes. It’s linked to heart defects, hearing loss, and other health issues.

Webbing of the neck and lymphedema (Option C) are features of Turner’s syndrome, a genetic condition that occurs when a female is born with only one full X chromosome (45, X instead of the usual 46, XX). It leads to short stature, infertility, and sometimes heart defects, kidney problems, and hearing loss. Individuals may also have learning difficulties, particularly with spatial reasoning.

Cleft lip and polydactyly (Option D) are features of Patau syndrome (Trisomy 13), a genetic disorder caused by an extra copy of chromosome 13. It leads to severe intellectual disability, cleft lip and palate, polydactyly (extra fingers or toes), heart defects, and brain abnormalities. Most affected infants have a short life expectancy, often not surviving beyond the first year.

questions.text: A girl presents with short stature, a webbed neck, thick calves, a shield-shaped chest, swelling of the ankle, and an increased carrying angle. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Turner syndrome

Explanation:

  • The clinical features described are characteristic of Turner syndrome, which is a genetic condition caused by the partial or complete absence of one of the X chromosomes (45 XO karyotype).
  • It leads to hypogonadism in phenotypic females.
  • Features of Turner Syndrome:

 

Down syndrome (Option B) results from Trisomy 21. It is associated with features such as intellectual disability, epicanthal folds, flat facial profile, and congenital heart defects but does not include the specific skeletal and physical features seen in Turner syndrome.

Patau syndrome (Option C) occurs due to trisomy 13, and its clinical features include microphthalmia, microcephaly, rocker bottom feet, polycystic kidney disease, and congenital heart disease, none of which are consistent with the features described in the question.

Edward syndrome (Option D) is caused by the presence of an extra copy of chromosome 18 (Trisomy 18) and is characterized by severe developmental delay, clenched fists, rocker-bottom feet, and heart defects, which differ significantly from the features seen in Turner syndrome.

questions.text: The family pedigree chart is given below. Identify the mode of inheritance of this condition.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Autosomal dominant

Explanation:

  • The disease is transmitted from father to son, ruling out X-linked inheritance & the condition appears in every generation, with both males & females affected, suggesting an autosomal dominant pattern.

 

Autosomal dominant inheritance pattern:

  • The mode of transmission is vertical. An affected person has an affected parent.
  • There is a 50% chance of the dominant trait being transmitted to offspring.
  • Both males and females are equally affected.
  • The dominant gene is expressed in heterozygotes.
  • Delayed age of onset.
  • The trait appears in every generation without skipping.
  • An unaffected offspring does not transmit the disease.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct about Huntington's chorea?

choices.text: It is a trinucleotide repeat disorder
There is a loss of function type of mutation
There are abnormal length repeats of CUG
Abnormality is seen due to a defect in chromosome 6

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) It is a trinucleotide repeat disorder

Explanation:

Huntington's chorea is a trinucleotide repeat disorder caused by the expansion of the CAG repeat in the HTT gene on chromosome 4.

Huntington's disease: HD is an autosomal dominant disorder caused by the degeneration of striatal neurons, leading to a progressive movement disorder and dementia. Symptoms include chorea, bradykinesia, and rigidity. It is relentlessly progressive and fatal, typically over 15 years.

  • Pathogenesis:
    • HD is a trinucleotide repeat expansion disease caused by a CAG repeat (Option C) in the HTT gene on chromosome 4p16.3 (Option D), encoding huntingtin protein.
    • Normal HTT genes have 6 to 35 CAG repeats, while pathogenic mutations have expanded repeats, leading to earlier disease onset with paternal transmission causing anticipation & the toxic gain-of-function (Option B) of mutant huntingtin is believed to be the primary pathogenic mechanism.
  • Morphology:
    • The brain exhibits atrophy of the caudate nucleus and putamen, along with ventricular dilation.
    • There is a loss of striatal neurons, particularly affecting GABAergic neurons in the caudate and putamen.
    • Gliosis is more extensive than usual due to neuronal loss.
  • Clinical features:
    • The loss of striatal neurons results in increased motor activity, causing choreoathetosis. Cognitive decline follows, with symptoms such as forgetfulness and dementia.
    • The disease usually manifests in the fourth or fifth decade, and motor symptoms typically precede cognitive symptoms.
    • The leading cause of death is often pneumonia, especially in advanced stages. Suicide rates are higher in HD patients.

questions.text: Premature ageing in Werner syndrome is due to:

choices.text: Increase in length of telomere due to decrease in telomerase activity

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Defect in DNA helicase

Explanation:

  • Werner syndrome, a rare autosomal recessive disorder, is characterised by premature ageing and accelerated development of age-related diseases.
  • It results from mutations in the WRN gene, which encodes a DNA helicase involved in DNA repair and maintenance of genomic stability.
  • Chromosomal damage accumulates rapidly due to the defective enzyme.
  • This damage mimics normal ageing at a faster rate, leading to premature ageing.
  • Similar conditions like Bloom syndrome and ataxia-telangiectasia also involve mutations in genes responsible for DNA repair.
  • These disorders result in genetic instability and accelerated ageing due to impaired DNA repair mechanisms.

 

Incorrect Options:

Increased telomerase activity (Option A) is typically seen in some cancers, where it allows cells to maintain telomere length and avoid senescence.

Increase in length of telomere due to decrease in telomerase activity (Option C) and Decreased telomerase activity (Option D): In Werner syndrome, telomere shortening occurs due to DNA repair defects rather than telomere maintenance problems. Telomerase activity is not significantly altered.

questions.text: Which of the following disorders is inherited in an X-linked dominant pattern?
questions.solution:
Rett syndrome is inherited in an X-linked dominant pattern, primarily affecting females.

 

X-linked dominant inheritance:

  • The gene responsible for the concerned trait or disorder is present on the X chromosome and can express itself both in homozygous and heterozygous conditions.
  • It is more commonly seen in females than males since females have two X chromosomes.
  • An affected male will transmit the disease to all his daughters but not sons.
  • An affected female can transmit the disease to both daughters and sons.
  • Conditions with X-linked dominant inheritance:
  • Rett syndrome.
  • Alport syndrome
  • Vitamin D-resistant rickets.
  • Incontinentia pigmenti.

 

The pedigree chart below shows an X-linked dominant pattern:

  • The affected mother of the first generation transmitted the disease to both son and daughter.
  • The affected father of the second generation transmitted the disease only to the daughters.

Duchenne muscular dystrophy (Option B) follows an X-linked recessive inheritance pattern.

Huntington’s disease (Option C) follows an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern.

Tuberous sclerosis (Option D) is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern.

Learning Objective:

  • X-linked dominance is more common in females.
  • Affected males transmit the disease only to their daughters.
  • Affected females transmit the disease to both daughters and sons.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis of a 14-year-old child who has short stature, widely placed nipples, and primary amenorrhea?
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option A: Turner syndrome

  • Turner syndrome, also known as 45,X or monosomy X, is a genetic condition that affects females. It occurs when one of the two X chromosomes is partially or completely missing. The syndrome can lead to a variety of physical and developmental features.

The symptoms mentioned in the question are characteristic of Turner syndrome:

  1. Short stature: Girls with Turner syndrome often experience growth failure and have shorter-than-average height.
  2. Nipples widely placed: One of the physical features commonly seen in Turner syndrome is a wide spacing between the nipples.
  3. Primary amenorrhea: Girls with Turner syndrome typically have delayed or absent puberty, leading to the absence of menstrual periods.

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Down syndrome (trisomy 21): Down syndrome is a genetic disorder caused by the presence of an extra copy of chromosome 21. It is characterized by distinct physical features, intellectual disability, and various health issues. However, the symptoms mentioned in the question, such as short stature, widely placed nipples, and primary amenorrhea, are not typical of Down syndrome. Therefore, Down syndrome is not the correct diagnosis in this case.

Option C: Edward syndrome (trisomy 18): Edward syndrome is a genetic disorder caused by the presence of an extra copy of chromosome 18. It is associated with multiple congenital abnormalities affecting various organ systems. However, the symptoms mentioned in the question, including short stature, widely placed nipples, and primary amenorrhea, are not specifically associated with Edward syndrome. Hence, Edward syndrome is not the correct diagnosis for the presented symptoms.

Option D: Patau syndrome (trisomy 13): Patau syndrome is a genetic disorder caused by the presence of an extra copy of chromosome 13. It is characterized by severe developmental issues, multiple congenital abnormalities, and intellectual disability. However, the symptoms described in the question, such as short stature, widely placed nipples, and primary amenorrhea, are not typically associated with Patau syndrome. Therefore, Patau syndrome is not the correct diagnosis for the given symptoms.

questions.text: Which of the following is the mode of inheritance in a patient suffering from red-green colour blindness?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - X-linked recessive:

  • Red-Green color blindness is often inherited in an X-linked recessive manner. The genes responsible for color vision are located on the X chromosome, and the condition is more prevalent in males due to their hemizygous nature.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Autosomal dominant: Red-Green color blindness is not typically inherited in an autosomal dominant manner. The condition is more commonly associated with sex-linked inheritance.

Option B - Autosomal recessive: Autosomal recessive inheritance is not the typical mode for Red-Green color blindness. The condition is more commonly associated with X-linked inheritance.

Option C - X-linked dominant: X-linked dominant inheritance is not the typical mode for Red-Green color blindness. The condition is more commonly associated with X-linked recessive inheritance.

questions.text: t(11,22) is best diagnosed by …………..
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B

  • FISH is a molecular cytogenetic technique that uses fluorescent probes to visualize specific DNA sequences. In the case of t(11,22) translocation, FISH can identify the rearrangement by detecting the fusion of the genes involved in the translocation. FISH is highly sensitive and specific for detecting chromosomal abnormalities, even at the level of individual genes.

Incorrect Options:

Option A. Conventional karyotyping: Conventional karyotyping involves examining the chromosomes' structure and number under a microscope. However, it may not provide sufficient resolution to detect small translocations like t(11,22).

Option C. Bone marrow aspiration: Bone marrow aspiration is a procedure to obtain a sample of bone marrow for examination under a microscope. While it can help diagnose certain conditions, it is not the primary method for detecting chromosomal translocations like t(11,22).

Option D. Next-generation sequencing (NGS): NGS is a powerful sequencing technology that allows the analysis of multiple genes and genetic variants simultaneously. It is primarily used for genetic testing, including the identification of specific mutations and genetic alterations. While NGS can detect genetic abnormalities, it may not be the most efficient method for diagnosing t(11,22) translocation specifically.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an aneuploidy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Bloom syndrome

Explanation:

  • Aneuploidy refers to a numerical abnormality in chromosomes — gain or loss of whole chromosomes.
  • Normal human chromosome number: 46 (2n)
    • Trisomy = 2n + 1 (47 chromosomes)
    • Monosomy = 2n – 1 (45 chromosomes)

Bloom Syndrome:

  • Genetic defect: Mutation in BLM gene on chromosome 15.
  • Autosomal recessive disorder caused by loss-of-function mutations in a DNA helicase that is required for homologous recombination repair in DNA repair.
  • Result: Defective DNA repair → Chromosomal instability → Predisposition to cancer.
  • Chromosome number is normal (46) - it’s a chromosomal instability disorder, not a numerical abnormality.

questions.text: What is the status of the marked individual?

choices.text: Has a disease of chronic origin

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Adopted from another family:

Explanation:

  • In standard pedigree notation:
    • An individual marked with brackets around the symbol indicates adoption.
    • If the brackets are dashed, it usually means adopted in (from another family).
    • If the brackets are solid, it usually means adopted out (given to another family).

  • Has a disease of chronic origin / Curable disease (Option B, C): would be indicated by shading or other symbols, not brackets.
  • Twin (Option D): represented by two siblings connected by a triangle or horizontal bar, not brackets.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents with headaches, visual disturbances, and hypertension. MRI brain shows a cerebellar hemangioblastoma, and abdominal imaging reveals multiple cysts in the kidneys along with a solid renal mass suggestive of renal cell carcinoma. His father had similar findings and died from a brain tumor in his 40s.Which of the following chromosomal abnormalities is most likely associated with his condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Deletion on chromosome 3p

Explanation:

  • The most likely diagnosis is Von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease, a hereditary condition characterised by the development of multiple cysts in the kidneys, pancreas, and other organs.
  • Genetics and pathogenesis:
    • Inheritance: Autosomal dominant
    • Gene: VHL tumour suppressor
    • Chromosomal location: 3p25–26
    • Pathogenesis:
      • The VHL gene product is part of a complex that degrades hypoxia-inducible factor (HIF) under normal oxygen levels.
      • Mutation or deletion → HIF is not degraded → ↑ VEGF, PDGF → abnormal angiogenesis and tumour formation.
  • Classic tumours/cysts:
    • CNS: Hemangioblastomas (esp. cerebellum, retina, spinal cord)
    • Kidneys: Simple cysts, clear cell RCC
    • Adrenal glands: Pheochromocytoma - headaches, palpitations, and sweating
    • Pancreas: Cysts, neuroendocrine tumours
    • Inner ear: Endolymphatic sac tumours

13q deletion (Option A): RB1 gene loss → retinoblastoma, osteosarcoma.

17p deletion (Option B): TP53 loss → Li-Fraumeni syndrome (sarcomas, breast cancer, brain tumors, adrenal carcinoma).

Trisomy 12 (Option D): common cytogenetic change in CLL.

questions.text: FBN1 gene mutation is seen in which of the following genetic disorders?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Marfan syndrome

Explanation:

  • Marfan syndrome is commonly associated with mutations in the FBN1 gene, which encodes the connective protein fibrillin on chromosome 15q21.

Pathophysiology:

  • Abnormal fibrillin-1 → defective microfibrils → weakened elastic fibres.
  • This leads to increased TGF-β activity, which contributes to the characteristic features of the syndrome.

Mode of inheritance:

  • Autosomal dominant.
  • Multisystem disorder with involvement of the connective tissues.

Clinical features:

Skeletal abnormalities:
  • Tall, thin build with long limbs (dolichostenomelia)
  • Arachnodactyly
  • Chest wall abnormalities like pectus excavatum/Pectus carinatum
  • Thumb sign( On folding the thumb, it will protrude beyond the ulnar border of palm) or wrist sign is positive
  • Increased joint laxity
  • Scoliosis

CVS abnormalities:
  • Aortic root dilation → aortic regurgitation
  • Risk of aortic aneurysm and dissection
  • Mitral valve prolapse
  • Arrhythmias

Eye abnormalities:

 
  • Ectopia lentis or subluxation of the lens of the eye
  • Blindness, Myopia

Pulmonary involvement:

  • Increased risk of pneumothorax

Diagnosis:

  • Marfan syndrome is clinically diagnosed using the Ghent criteria

Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (Option A): Usually due to collagen synthesis defects (type III or type V collagen), not FBN1.

Homocystinuria (Option C): Due to cystathionine β-synthase deficiency → high homocysteine levels; may have marfanoid habitus but with downward lens dislocation and thrombosis risk.

Von Hippel–Lindau syndrome (Option D): Due to VHL gene mutation on chromosome 3p, not FBN1; characterized by hemangioblastomas, renal cell carcinoma, and pheochromocytomas.

questions.text: A lymphoma characterised by the presence of centrocytes and centroblasts, along with BCL2 positivity and CD10 expression, is most commonly associated with which chromosomal translocation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) t(14;18)

Explanation:

  • The given HPE findings of the presence of centrocytes and centroblasts are consistent with Follicular lymphoma, which is associated with BCL2- gene translocation and CD10+; the chromosomal translocation associated with it is t(14:18).
  • Follicular lymphoma (FL) is a malignant neoplasm originating from germinal centre B-cells, characterised by the t(14;18) translocation leading to overexpression of BCL2.
  • Clinically, it presents with painless lymphadenopathy and may include systemic symptoms.
  • Histopathologically, FL exhibits a nodular growth pattern with centrocytes(Small cells with cleaved nuclei and scanty cytosol) and centroblasts(Larger cells with open nuclear chromatin, several nucleoli)
  • Immunohistochemistry shows positivity for CD10/19/20, BCL2, and BCL6, and negativity for CD5.
  • Management focuses on palliative approaches due to its indolent but incurable nature.

Incorrect Options:

t(2;5) (Option A): This translocation is associated with Anaplastic large cell lymphoma. It is seen in children or young adults. It is associated with an ALK gene mutation on chromosome 2. Histopathology reveals large anaplastic cells with horseshoe-shaped nuclei and voluminous cytoplasm (Hallmark cells/Doughnut cells). It usually presents with soft tissue involvement (mimicking metastatic carcinoma).

 

t(8;14) (Option B): This translocation is associated with Burkitt’s lymphoma.

  • Histopathological examination reveals numerous mitotic and apoptotic cells, nuclear remnants phagocytosed by benign macrophages with abundant clear cytoplasm, creating a characteristic "starry sky" pattern.
  • Immunohistochemistry shows positivity for IgM, CD19, CD20, CD10, and BCL6, but negativity for BCL2.

t(11;14) (Option D): This translocation is associated with Mantle cell lymphoma.

  • Immunohistochemistry shows positivity for Cyclin D1, CD19, CD20, surface immunoglobulins (usually IgM and IgD), and CD5, but CD23 is negative and HPE shows small lymphoid cells with irregular nuclear outlines, condensed chromatin, and scanty cytoplasm

questions.text: Which of the following diseases exhibits the inheritance pattern shown?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Kearns-Sayre syndrome

Explanation:

  • The pattern shown in the pedigree is Mitochondrial Inheritance, which is characteristic of Kearns-Sayre syndrome
  • Mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) is inherited solely maternally. Thus, females with causative mtDNA may transmit the disease to all offspring. However, the disease's expression is variable due to heteroplasmy (the combination of both mutant and wild DNA in offspring).
  • Mitochondrial diseases thus affect organs with prominent aerobic metabolism. Skeletal muscle (myopathy) and nervous system involvement are common.

Some other examples are:

  • Chronic progressive external ophthalmoplegia (CPEO)/ Kearns-Sayre syndrome (KSS)
  • Leigh syndrome (Option A)
  • Mitochondrial encephalomyopathy with lactic acidosis and stroke-like episodes (MELAS)
  • Myoclonic epilepsy with ragged red fibers (MERRF)
  • Neuropathy, ataxia, and retinitis pigmentosa (NARP)
  • Primary coenzyme Q10 (CoQ10) deficiency

Incorrect Options:

Williams syndrome (Option B) is caused by a microdeletion on chromosome 7, it follows an autosomal dominant pattern, not mitochondrial inheritance.

Achondroplasia (Option C) is a result of a mutation in the FGFR3 gene, achondroplasia is inherited in an autosomal dominant manner and does not involve mitochondrial DNA.

Cystic fibrosis (Option D) is an autosomal recessive disorder due to mutations in the CFTR gene, cystic fibrosis is inherited via nuclear DNA, not mitochondria.

Prader-Willi syndrome (Option C) occurs when there is maternal disomy of chromosome 15, leading to the absence of the paternal allele. Key features include intellectual disability (MR), short stature, and obesity/hyperphagia due to elevated levels of the hormone ghrelin.


Angelman syndrome (Option D), often referred to as "Happy Puppet" syndrome, arises when there is a paternal disomy of chromosome 15, leading to the absence of the maternal allele. Key features include seizures, ataxia, intellectual disability (MR), and inappropriate laughter.

questions.text: A teenager was brought to the OPD with complaints of delayed fertility and primary amenorrhea. Physical examination reveals a webbed neck and widely spaced nipples. Which karyotype is associated with a given condition?

Explanation:

  • It is characterised by complete or partial monosomy of the X chromosome, leading to hypogonadism in phenotypic females.
  • Clinical features: Short stature, webbed neck, lymphedema, and primary amenorrhea.

 

The image below shows karyotyping in Turner syndrome.

 

47, XXY (Option B) is Klinefelter syndrome, which occurs in males with an extra X chromosome, leading to hypogonadism, small testes, gynecomastia, reduced body/facial hair, and infertility. While it is associated with tall stature and sometimes mild intellectual disabilities, it does not present with features like a webbed neck, widely spaced nipples, or primary amenorrhea, which are characteristic of Turner syndrome.

47, XXX (Option C) is Triple X Syndrome, which occurs in females with an extra X chromosome. It is usually asymptomatic or causes mild developmental delays but does not present with primary amenorrhea or webbed neck, which are typical of Turner syndrome.

47, XYY (Option D) is Jacob's Syndrome, which occurs in males with an extra Y chromosome, leading to tall stature and mild intellectual disabilities, but it does not cause primary amenorrhea, webbed neck, or widely spaced nipples, which are characteristic of Turner syndrome.

questions.text: Which mutation is linked to the Philadelphia chromosome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Reciprocal translocation

Explanation:

  • The Philadelphia Chromosome is a reciprocal translocation involving chromosomes 9 and 22 that is commonly identified in CML (chronic myeloid leukaemia).
  • The two chromosome breaks lie within:
    • ABL gene on chromosome 9
    • BCR (breakpoint cluster region) gene on chromosome 22.
  • Nonhomologous end-joining causes a reciprocal translocation, resulting in the formation of an oncogenic BCR-ABL fusion gene on the derivative chromosome 22, known as the Philadelphia chromosome.
  • BCR-ABL fusion genes encode chimeric BCR-ABL proteins with constitutive tyrosine kinase activity.

 

Inversion (Option A): In an inversion, a segment of a chromosome is flipped within the same chromosome but remains in its original location. Example of inversion-related disorder: Hemophilia A (due to intrachromosomal inversion in the F8 gene).

Deletion (Option B) involves the loss of a chromosome segment, leading to missing genetic material. Example of deletion-related disorder: Cri-du-chat syndrome (chromosome 5p deletion)

Insertion (Option D) occurs when a segment of one chromosome is inserted into another chromosome without reciprocal exchange. Example of insertion-related disorder: Some cases of hereditary cancer syndromes due to gene insertions.

questions.text: What does the given pedigree chart indicate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Mitochondrial Disorder

Explanation:

  • The given pedigree suggests a Mitochondrial Disorder, where a defect in maternal mtDNA is inherited by all offspring, while a defect in paternal mtDNA is not passed on to any offspring.
  • They involve defects in the mitochondria, which are responsible for producing energy in the form of ATP through oxidative phosphorylation.
  • Mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) is inherited exclusively from the mother (females with pathogenic mtDNA can pass the disease to their offspring).
  • They affect organs with prominent aerobic metabolism (commonly skeletal muscle (myopathy) and nervous system).
  • Some examples are:
    • Leber hereditary optic neuropathy (LHON)

Autosomal Dominant (AD) (Option A) inheritance follows a vertical transmission pattern, where an affected individual has an affected parent, and there is a 50% chance of passing the dominant trait to offspring, with both males and females equally affected.

Autosomal Recessive (AR) (Option B) inheritance shows horizontal transmission, with the trait appearing in siblings while parents are unaffected, often in consanguineous marriages. Carriers have a 25% chance of an affected child, and males and females are equally affected. It includes most inborn errors of metabolism.

X-linked Recessive (XLR) (Option D) inheritance means females (XX) are carriers, while males are affected by the disease.

questions.text: All of the following are used to detect abnormal gene sequences, except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Flow cytometry

Explanation:

  • Flow cytometry is not used to detect abnormal gene sequences.
  • Flow cytometry is a technique primarily used to measure the physical and chemical properties of cells, such as cell size, granularity, and protein expression.
  • It has numerous uses in genomic studies, with a high focus on monitoring cell cycle phases and cell viability, and is more often employed for immunophenotyping and cell sorting.

Fluorescence in situ Hybridization (FISH) (Option A) detects DNA sequence alterations like translocations, deletions, and amplifications using fluorescent probes to bind specific DNA regions, identifying chromosomal abnormalities.
RFLP analysis (Option B) (Restriction Fragment Length Polymorphism) detects DNA sequence variations by analyzing the lengths of restriction enzyme-digested DNA fragments.

Pyrosequencing (Option C) is a type of DNA sequencing technology that can directly read DNA sequences by measuring the release of pyrophosphate during nucleotide incorporation. It allows for the detection of mutations, SNPs, and other genetic alterations.

Incomplete penetrance (Option A) refers to a situation where some individuals inherit the mutant gene but are phenotypically normal.

Autosomal Recessive (Option C) inheritance requires two copies of the mutation for the trait to be expressed. It typically shows horizontal transmission and can skip generations.

Pseudo dominance (Option D) occurs when a recessive allele appears to be expressed in the heterozygous condition due to the limited number of crossovers between linked genes.

questions.text: The SRY gene is present on:

questions.text: Identify the type of inheritance?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Autosomal Dominant Inheritance:

  • In autosomal dominant inheritance, a single copy of the mutated gene from one parent is enough to cause the trait or disorder.
  • The trait or disorder will be present in every generation, as affected individuals pass the mutated gene to their offspring.
  • Individuals with one affected parent have a 50% chance of inheriting the trait.
  • For example, if a parent has a dominant genetic disorder like Huntington's disease, there's a 50% chance their child will inherit the disorder.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Autosomal Recessive Inheritance:

  • In autosomal recessive inheritance, two copies of the mutated gene (one from each parent) are required to manifest the trait or disorder.
  • Carriers of a single mutated gene are usually healthy but can pass on the mutation to their offspring.
  • The trait or disorder might skip generations if carriers do not have affected children.
  • When two carriers have a child, there's a 25% chance the child will have the disorder, a 50% chance of being a carrier, and a 25% chance of having neither the disorder nor being a carrier.
  • An example is cystic fibrosis.

Option C - X-Linked Dominant Inheritance:

  • X-linked dominant inheritance involves a mutated gene on the X chromosome.
  • A single copy of the mutated gene on one of the X chromosomes is sufficient to cause the trait or disorder in females (since they have two X chromosomes) and in males (who have one X chromosome).
  • Affected fathers pass the disorder to all their daughters, but not to their sons.
  • Affected mothers have a 50% chance of passing the disorder to both sons and daughters.
  • An example is Rett syndrome.

Option D - X-Linked Recessive Inheritance:

  • X-linked recessive inheritance also involves a mutated gene on the X chromosome.
  • Males are more commonly affected because they have only one X chromosome.
  • Carrier mothers (with one normal and one mutated X chromosome) can pass the mutation to their sons (who get their X chromosome from the mother) and to half of their daughters (who inherit the mutated X chromosome).
  • Carrier fathers pass the mutated gene only to their daughters, who become carriers.
  • An example is color blindness.

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman who has the thalassemia trait visits the clinic for genetic counseling. Her husband is also confirmed to have the thalassemia trait. Considering their genetic background, what is the likelihood of their next offspring having thalassemia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - 25%:

  • When both parents are carriers of the thalassemia trait (heterozygous), the Punnett square analysis shows that there's a 25% chance for their offspring to inherit two mutated copies of the gene (one from each parent), resulting in thalassemia. There is a 50% chance of inheriting one normal and one mutated gene (being a carrier like the parents), and a 25% chance of inheriting two normal copies of the gene.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 100%: This would mean that all of their offspring would definitely have thalassemia, which is not the case. Thalassemia is an autosomal recessive genetic disorder, meaning that both copies of the gene need to carry the mutation for the disorder to manifest. Since both parents have thalassemia trait, they each carry one normal copy of the gene and one mutated copy. Therefore, there is a chance that their offspring may inherit one normal copy from one parent and one mutated copy from the other, resulting in carrying the thalassemia trait, but not necessarily having thalassemia.

Option B - 50%: This would imply that each offspring has a 50% chance of having thalassemia. While it's true that each child has a 50% chance of inheriting the mutated gene from either parent, the probability of them having thalassemia depends on both copies of the gene being mutated, which is less likely.

Option C - 75%: This would suggest that there's a higher likelihood of having thalassemia than not. However, the probability of an offspring having thalassemia is not this high. It's important to remember that the trait they both have is the heterozygous form (thalassemia trait), which means they each have one normal gene and one mutated gene. This significantly reduces the probability of their offspring having thalassemia

questions.text: With which pattern of disease inheritance is consanguinity associated?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Autosomal Recessive:

  • Consanguinity refers to a close blood relationship between the parents.
  • Autosomal recessive diseases are more likely to occur in the offspring of consanguineous couples.
  • This is because the parents may both carry a single copy of a recessive gene mutation, and when they have children together, there is an increased chance of both parents passing on the mutated gene, resulting in the expression of the disease phenotype in the offspring.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Autosomal Dominant:

  • Autosomal dominant diseases can occur in the offspring of consanguineous couples, but they are not specifically associated with consanguinity.
  • Autosomal dominant diseases can also arise from de novo mutations or occur in non-consanguineous families.

Option C - X-Linked Recessive:

  • X-linked recessive diseases are inherited through the X chromosome.
  • Although consanguinity can increase the likelihood of inheriting X-linked recessive diseases, it is not the characteristic pattern associated with consanguinity.

Option D - X-Linked Dominant:

  • X-linked dominant diseases can also occur in the offspring of consanguineous couples, but they are less common and not specifically associated with consanguinity.

  • The accumulation of beta-amyloid plaques and neurofibrillary tangles in the brain, characteristic of Alzheimer disease, occurs at an earlier age and progresses more rapidly in individuals with Down syndrome.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: Alpha-1 antitrypsin is the major inhibitor of which enzyme?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Elastase:

  • Elastase is an enzyme that breaks down elastin, a protein found in elastic tissues such as the lungs and blood vessels.
  • Alpha-1 antitrypsin is a potent inhibitor of elastase, preventing its excessive activity and protecting tissues from damage.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: A boy was diagnosed with a medical condition that is believed to have been passed down from his grandmother to his father, and now to him. What is the pattern of inheritance in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Autosomal Dominant:

  • Autosomal dominant inheritance occurs when the gene responsible for the condition is located on one of the autosomes (non-sex chromosomes), typically on one of the numbered chromosomes.
  • In this pattern of inheritance, a single copy of the gene is sufficient to express the trait.
  • If the boy inherited the condition from his grandmother and his father, it indicates that the gene is on one of the autosomes and is dominant.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and D are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of the correct answer.
